location: Elsinore. A platform before the castle.

lines.text: FRANCISCO at his post. Enter to him BERNARDO

lines.speaker: bernardo
lines.text: Whos there

lines.speaker: francisco
lines.text: Nay, answer me: stand, and unfold yourself.

lines.speaker: bernardo
lines.text: Long live the king!

lines.speaker: francisco
lines.text: Bernardo

lines.speaker: bernardo
lines.text: He.

lines.speaker: francisco
lines.text: You come most carefully upon your hour.

lines.speaker: bernardo
lines.text: Tis now struck twelve get thee to bed, Francisco.

lines.speaker: francisco
lines.text: For this relief much thanks: tis bitter cold, And I am sick at heart.

lines.speaker: bernardo
lines.text: Have you had quiet guard

lines.speaker: francisco
lines.text: Not a mouse stirring.

lines.speaker: bernardo
lines.text: Well, good night. If you do meet Horatio and Marcellus, The rivals of my watch, bid them make haste.

lines.speaker: francisco
lines.text: I think I hear them. Stand, ho! Whos there
Enter HORATIO and MARCELLUS

lines.speaker: horatio
lines.text: Friends to this ground.

lines.speaker: marcellus
lines.text: And liegemen to the Dane.

lines.speaker: francisco
lines.text: Give you good night.

lines.speaker: marcellus
lines.text: O, farewell, honest soldier: Who hath relieved you

lines.speaker: francisco
lines.text: Bernardo has my place. Give you good night.
Exit

lines.speaker: marcellus
lines.text: Holla! Bernardo!

lines.speaker: bernardo
lines.text: Say, What, is Horatio there

lines.speaker: horatio
lines.text: A piece of him.

lines.speaker: bernardo
lines.text: Welcome, Horatio: welcome, good Marcellus.

lines.speaker: marcellus
lines.text: What, has this thing appeard again tonight

lines.speaker: bernardo
lines.text: I have seen nothing.

lines.speaker: marcellus
lines.text: Horatio says tis but our fantasy, And will not let belief take hold of him Touching this dreaded sight, twice seen of us: Therefore I have entreated him along With us to watch the minutes of this night That if again this apparition come, He may approve our eyes and speak to it.

lines.speaker: horatio
lines.text: Tush, tush, twill not appear.

lines.speaker: bernardo
lines.text: Sit down awhile And let us once again assail your ears, That are so fortified against our story What we have two nights seen.

lines.speaker: horatio
lines.text: Well, sit we down, And let us hear Bernardo speak of this.

lines.speaker: bernardo
lines.text: Last night of all, When yond same star thats westward from the pole Had made his course to illume that part of heaven Where now it burns, Marcellus and myself, The bell then beating one,
Enter Ghost

lines.speaker: marcellus
lines.text: Peace, break thee off look, where it comes again!

lines.speaker: bernardo
lines.text: In the same figure, like the king thats dead.

lines.speaker: marcellus
lines.text: Thou art a scholar speak to it, Horatio.

lines.speaker: bernardo
lines.text: Looks it not like the king  mark it, Horatio.

lines.speaker: horatio
lines.text: Most like: it harrows me with fear and wonder.

lines.speaker: bernardo
lines.text: It would be spoke to.

lines.speaker: marcellus
lines.text: Question it, Horatio.

lines.speaker: horatio
lines.text: What art thou that usurpst this time of night, Together with that fair and warlike form In which the majesty of buried Denmark Did sometimes march by heaven I charge thee, speak!

lines.speaker: marcellus
lines.text: It is offended.

lines.speaker: bernardo
lines.text: See, it stalks away!

lines.speaker: horatio
lines.text: Stay! speak, speak! I charge thee, speak!
Exit Ghost

lines.speaker: marcellus
lines.text: Tis gone, and will not answer.

lines.speaker: bernardo
lines.text: How now, Horatio! you tremble and look pale: Is not this something more than fantasy What think you ont

lines.speaker: horatio
lines.text: Before my God, I might not this believe Without the sensible and true avouch Of mine own eyes.

lines.speaker: marcellus
lines.text: Is it not like the king

lines.speaker: horatio
lines.text: As thou art to thyself: Such was the very armour he had on When he the ambitious Norway combated So frownd he once, when, in an angry parle, He smote the sledded Polacks on the ice. Tis strange.

lines.speaker: marcellus
lines.text: Thus twice before, and jump at this dead hour, With martial stalk hath he gone by our watch.

lines.speaker: horatio
lines.text: In what particular thought to work I know not But in the gross and scope of my opinion, This bodes some strange eruption to our state.

lines.speaker: marcellus
lines.text: Good now, sit down, and tell me, he that knows, Why this same strict and most observant watch So nightly toils the subject of the land, And why such daily cast of brazen cannon, And foreign mart for implements of war Why such impress of shipwrights, whose sore task Does not divide the Sunday from the week What might be toward, that this sweaty haste Doth make the night jointlabourer with the day: Who ist that can inform me

lines.speaker: horatio
lines.text: That can I At least, the whisper goes so. Our last king, Whose image even but now appeard to us, Was, as you know, by Fortinbras of Norway, Thereto prickd on by a most emulate pride, Dared to the combat in which our valiant Hamlet For so this side of our known world esteemd him Did slay this Fortinbras who by a seald compact, Well ratified by law and heraldry, Did forfeit, with his life, all those his lands Which he stood seized of, to the conqueror: Against the which, a moiety competent Was gaged by our king which had returnd To the inheritance of Fortinbras, Had he been vanquisher as, by the same covenant, And carriage of the article designd, His fell to Hamlet. Now, sir, young Fortinbras, Of unimproved mettle hot and full, Hath in the skirts of Norway here and there Sharkd up a list of lawless resolutes, For food and diet, to some enterprise That hath a stomach int which is no other As it doth well appear unto our state But to recover of us, by strong hand And terms compulsatory, those foresaid lands So by his father lost: and this, I take it, Is the main motive of our preparations, The source of this our watch and the chief head Of this posthaste and romage in the land.

lines.speaker: bernardo
lines.text: I think it be no other but een so: Well may it sort that this portentous figure Comes armed through our watch so like the king That was and is the question of these wars.

lines.speaker: horatio
lines.text: A mote it is to trouble the minds eye. In the most high and palmy state of Rome, A little ere the mightiest Julius fell, The graves stood tenantless and the sheeted dead Did squeak and gibber in the Roman streets: As stars with trains of fire and dews of blood, Disasters in the sun and the moist star Upon whose influence Neptunes empire stands Was sick almost to doomsday with eclipse: And even the like precurse of fierce events, As harbingers preceding still the fates And prologue to the omen coming on, Have heaven and earth together demonstrated Unto our climatures and countrymen. But soft, behold! lo, where it comes again! Ill cross it, though it blast me. Stay, illusion! If thou hast any sound, or use of voice, Speak to me: If there be any good thing to be done, That may to thee do ease and grace to me, Speak to me: If thou art privy to thy countrys fate, Which, happily, foreknowing may avoid, O, speak! Or if thou hast uphoarded in thy life Extorted treasure in the womb of earth, For which, they say, you spirits oft walk in death, Speak of it: stay, and speak! Stop it, Marcellus.
Reenter Ghost
Cock crows

lines.speaker: marcellus
lines.text: Shall I strike at it with my partisan

lines.speaker: horatio
lines.text: Do, if it will not stand.

lines.speaker: bernardo
lines.text: Tis here!

lines.speaker: horatio
lines.text: Tis here!

lines.speaker: marcellus
lines.text: Tis gone! We do it wrong, being so majestical, To offer it the show of violence For it is, as the air, invulnerable, And our vain blows malicious mockery.
Exit Ghost

lines.speaker: bernardo
lines.text: It was about to speak, when the cock crew.

lines.speaker: horatio
lines.text: And then it started like a guilty thing Upon a fearful summons. I have heard, The cock, that is the trumpet to the morn, Doth with his lofty and shrillsounding throat Awake the god of day and, at his warning, Whether in sea or fire, in earth or air, The extravagant and erring spirit hies To his confine: and of the truth herein This present object made probation.

lines.speaker: marcellus
lines.text: It faded on the crowing of the cock. Some say that ever gainst that season comes Wherein our Saviours birth is celebrated, The bird of dawning singeth all night long: And then, they say, no spirit dares stir abroad The nights are wholesome then no planets strike, No fairy takes, nor witch hath power to charm, So hallowd and so gracious is the time.

lines.speaker: horatio
lines.text: So have I heard and do in part believe it. But, look, the morn, in russet mantle clad, Walks oer the dew of yon high eastward hill: Break we our watch up and by my advice, Let us impart what we have seen tonight Unto young Hamlet for, upon my life, This spirit, dumb to us, will speak to him. Do you consent we shall acquaint him with it, As needful in our loves, fitting our duty

lines.speaker: marcellus
lines.text: Lets dot, I pray and I this morning know Where we shall find him most conveniently.
Exeunt
